Mechanisms: If It Moves It Breaks                                              Mechanisms: If It Moves It Breaks                    Menu      Skip to content      Home Class Schedule Contact us Course Description Homework Housekeeping                                                             and more links…                           Stuart Heys wanted to share this one with you guys. Russian mousetrap madness:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nRJF8B7h9uw   I think we also mentioned these videos, bringing an old letter press back to life. First with nice use of an inclined plane:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PycfcTb0Z6I  and then really going for it with a torch:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IgT2Nbz0wiM                      This entry was posted in Uncategorized on March 2, 2015 by Stephan von Muehlen .                                             Links!                           For when you are day-dreaming about how awesome your final project is going to be, or wondering where in the hell you are being dragged to on this field trip…   Where we are going:     www.stu.nyc   www.refactory.co   www.poursteady.com   www.swayspace.com   www.moeyinc.com   www.breakfastny.com     Cool stuff your classmates found:     https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MYGJ9jrbpvg   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eR6FA_8jGAc   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_qR1gndF5zQ   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wE3fmFTtP9g   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PYGB8wKftdI   https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=dAa6bOWB8qY   http://itp.smorad.com/2015/02/if-it-moves-it-breaks/   http://gizmodo.com/alexander-graham-bells-failed-flying-machine-reborn-as-1148632842   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bal4qlnjLuo   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAyLX2hY7E0   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lgOxWPGsJNY     Videos of how things really get made recommended by Stuart Heys (we will be visiting his machine shop):       mechanical spiral bevel gear generating   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gj2szHk0OCU         straight bevel gear generating   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8H-FDtDMfMg         hobbing   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RG4mrzmGgcg         planar wire forming   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SQIYZ-iKuG4         cnc spring foming   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=km9KmVr2TIE   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OjqdqLKjMnQ         four slide   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JtrNW7j8MG0         cam operated screw machine   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6VpCBk7FahI         multispindle screw machine   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pfOOHCTsEng         swiss type lathe (bar fed with non-round extrusion)   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jRwMkY2rwwo       ring forging   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDyWyDP3cvs       What an A+ project might look like :     http://trotify.com/                    This entry was posted in Uncategorized on February 25, 2015 by Stephan von Muehlen .                                             Some more info on the chain reaction…                           When we run the chain reactions, we will want to run them a couple times, hopefully out in the common space of the 4th floor, then probably separate them into individual parts and run them again back  in the class room, and talk about them. We would love to see your process when we talk about your Machines. Before you make your final parts you are probably going to do some simple prototypes to show yourself that it will take the alotted time, or knock over the next part, so show us how you tested/prototyped that part.   So, a couple points to emphasize that we didnt in class:  Document your chain reaction. We will ask you to put up pictures or sketches showing how you tested your theories of your machines, or prototyped out your parts. Take pictures, make sketches, put em out when we talk about your Machine. I suppose if you all document the stuff on your individual blogs/sites, we could pull those up during discussion, rather than printing out a bunch of stuff, if you prefer.   Make your Machine re-settable. If it absolutely has to explode in an enormous fireball, then bring spare parts to do it again a couple times, but ideally this is a machine you can re-set, re-use.   Thanks,  Pete and Stephan                  This entry was posted in Uncategorized on February 8, 2015 by Stephan von Muehlen .                                             The Beginning Engineers’ Checklist and Akin’s Laws                           Hey folks,   These lists are incredible practical, insightful, and kind of funny. Please read them and come prepared to discuss them in class next week.  Be able to share at least one example of how you applied some of this advice to the mousetrap/chain reaction assignment!   http://makezine.com/2011/03/30/the-beginning-mechanical-engineers-checklist/   and   http://spacecraft.ssl.umd.edu/akins_laws.html                    This entry was posted in Uncategorized on February 6, 2015 by Stephan von Muehlen .                                             Hello folks                           We are thrilled you have decided to take our class. As you can probably tell by now, your instructors like to make physical “stuff” and we will probably keep this site pretty bare-bones. That said, you can find the basic stuff here–course description, schedule, homework. Who knows, maybe as the class develops, we will get fancy and add more content.   See you on Friday!   –Stephan and Pete                  This entry was posted in Uncategorized on February 3, 2015 by Stephan von Muehlen .
